text: a few years ago hal varian came up with
a really interesting piece of work
called how much information and
he and his team started to quantify how
much data humans are creating
and the conclusion is that over the next
four years or less we are going to at
least double the amount of
data generated by the human species
across time
let me repeat that again over the next
four years we're likely to
double the amount of data generated by
the human species across time
that sounds absolutely ludicrous because
when you think of all the words and all
the songs and all the
you know books and everything else
yes
but then come back to your own life
in the measure that you start to think
how many photographs did you take when
you were using kodak film
and how many co photographs are you
taking now that you can use your little
cell phone
and use your digital camera and just
download it onto your computer which by
the way you've now got a double the
memory because you have so many pictures
on there
and then what happens when the data
density comes to film and what happens
with the new flip cameras
where you can have high definition
television come out of a 200 device that
everybody's going to be wandering around
with
and then you think of what's happening
in medical imaging and then you start
thinking of what's happening in
astronomical imaging
and then you think of the number of
books that were published across time
versus the number of blogs that are
published today
and you begin to get a sense of
how something it sounds wild and
outrageous
is actually something that all of us are
living every day
